CH E 5.title: Introduction to Chemical Engineering Design
CH E 5.description: Introduction to the design and analysis of processes involving chemical change in the context of chemical and biomolecular engineering. Students learn mathematical, empirical, and conceptual strategies to analyze chemical processes to assess product quality, economics, safety, and environmental issues. Focus topics include an overview of chemical and biomolecular engineering, evaluating and analyzing data, flowsheets, material and energy balances, economics, and unit operations.

CH E 10.title: Material and Energy Balances
CH E 10.prereq_description: Chemical Engineering 5 (may be taken concurrently); Chemistry 1A-B-C or
CH E 10.comments: Space may be limited and registration priority will be given to Chemical Engineering and COE majors.
CH E 10.description: Elementary principles and problem solving skills required for quantitative analysis of chemical processes. Topics to be covered include macroscopic material and energy balances, reaction stoichiometry, elementary thermodynamics, and phase equilibria associated with chemical engineering processes and unit operations.

CH E 99.title: Introduction to Research
CH E 99.prereq_description: Consent of instructor and undergraduate advisor.
CH E 99.comments: May be repeated for credit to a maximum of 6 units. Students are limited to5 units per quarter and 30 units total in all 98/99/198/199/199DC/199RA courses combined.
CH E 99.description: Directed study, normally experimental, to be arranged with individual faculty members. Course offers exceptional students an opportunity to participate in a research group.

CH E 102.title: Biomaterials and Biosurfaces
CH E 102.comments: Not open for credit to students who have completed Chemical Engineering 121.
CH E 102.description: Fundamentals of natural and artificial biomaterials and biosurfaces with emphasis on molecular level structure and function and their interactions with the body. Design issues of grafts and biopolymers. Basic biological, biophysical and biochemical systems reviewed for nonbiologists.
CH E 102.recommended_prep: Basic physical chemistry, chemistry, physics, thermodynamics and   biology.

CH E 107.title: Introduction to Biological Processing
CH E 107.description: Familiarizes engineering students with biological processing and production at multiple scales. Chemical engineering principles will be infused with key biological concepts, including an introduction to biochemistry, cell biology, and molecular biology.

CH E 110A.title: Chemical Engineering Thermodynamics
CH E 110A.prereq_description: Chemical Engineering 5; Chemical Engineering 10; Mathematics 4B or 4BI.
CH E 110A.comments: Space may be limited and registration priority will be given to Chemical Engineering and CoE majors.
CH E 110A.description: Use of the laws of thermodynamics to analyze processes encountered in engineering practice, including cycles and flows. Equations-of-state for describing properties of fluids and mixtures. Applications, including engines, turbines, refrigeration and power plant cycles, phase equilibria, and chemical-reaction equilibria.

CH E 110B.title: Chemical Engineering Thermodynamics
CH E 110B.prereq_description: Chemical Engineering 110A with a minimum grade of C-; Mathematics 4B or
CH E 110B.description: Extension of Chemical Engineering 110A to cover mixtures and multiphase equilibrium. Liquid-vapor separations calculations are emphasized. Introduction to equations of state for mixtures.

CH E 118.title: Technical Communication of Chemical Engineering
CH E 118.description: Provides an introduction to technical communication in the form of writing reports and oral presentations. Emphasis placed on how to analyze and present data; critical thinking; organization, logic and constructing a technical narrative; literature searching and citations for written reports; and how to give oral presentations. Includes various lectures on technical communication, individual and group assignments, and peer-review exercises.

CH E 119.title: Current Events in Chemical Engineering
CH E 119.description: Assigned readings in technical journals on current events of interest to chemical engineers. Student groups present oral reports on reading assignments pertaining to new technologies, discoveries, industry challenges, society/government issues, professional and ethical responsibilites.

CH E 120A.title: Transport Processes
CH E 120A.prereq_description: Chemical Engineering 10 with a minimum grade of C- (may be taken
CH E 120A.description: Introductory course in conceptual understanding and mathematical analysis of problems in fluid dynamics of relevance to Chemical Engineering. Emphasis is placed on performing microscopic and macroscopic mathematical analysis to understand fluid motion in response to forces.

CH E 120B.title: Transport Processes
CH E 120B.prereq_description: Chemical Engineering 10 with minimum grade of C-; Chemical Engineering
CH E 120B.description: Introductory course in the mathematical analysis of conductive, convective and radiative heat transfer with practical applications to design of heat exchange equipment and use.

CH E 120C.title: Transport Processes
CH E 120C.prereq_description: Chemical Engineering 10 with a minimum grade of C-; Chemical Engineering
CH E 120C.description: Introductory course in the fundamentals of mass transfer with applications to the design of mass transfer equipment.

CH E 121.title: Colloids and Biosurfaces
CH E 121.comments: Not open for credit to students who have completed Chemical Enginerring 102.
CH E 121.description: Basic forces and interactions between atoms, molecules, small particles and extended surfaces. Special features and interactions associated with (soft) biological molecules, biomaterials and surfaces: lipids, proteins, fibrous molecules (DNA), biological membranes, hydrophobic and hydrophilic interactions, bio-specific and non-equilibrium interactions.
CH E 121.recommended_prep: Basic physical chemistry, chemistry, physics, thermodynamics and biology.

CH E 124.title: Advanced Topics in Transport Phenomena/Safety
CH E 124.prereq_description: Chemical Engineering 120A-B-C; or, Mechanical Engineering 151A-B and Mechanical Engineering 152A.
CH E 124.description: Hazard identification and assessments, runaway reactions, emergency relief.Plant accidents and saftey issues. Dispersion and consequences of releases.

CH E 125.title: Principles of Bioengineering
CH E 125.description: Applications of engineering to biological and medical systems. Introduction to drug delivery, tissue engineering, and modern biomedical devices. Design and applications of these systems are discussed.

CH E 126.title: Non-Newtonian Fluids, Soft Materials and Chemical Products
CH E 126.description: Overview of soft materials (suspensions, gels, polymers, surfactants, emulsions, powders and granules) that arise in diverse industries, including consumer products, foods, advanced materials, biotechnology, and mineral and energy production. Influence of non-Newtonian rheology (shear-thickening and thinning, viscoelasticity, extension-thickening, yield stresses, normal stress differences, and metastability) upon handling, processing, production, and performance of chemical products. Strategies to design chemical products that meet performance targets, and to scale-up production. Real-world case studies and classroom demonstrations.

CH E 128.title: Separation Processes
CH E 128.prereq_description: Chemical Engineering 10, and 110A-B; open to Engineering majors only.
CH E 128.description: Basic principles and design techniques of equilibrium-stage separation processes. Emphasis is placed on binary distillation, liquid-liquid extraction, and multicomponent distillation.

CH E 132A.title: Analytical Methods in Chemical Engineering
CH E 132A.description: Develop analytical tools to solve elementary partial differential equations and boundary value problems. Separation of variables, Laplace transforms, Sturm-  Liouville theory, generalized Fourier analysis, and computer math tools.

CH E 132B.title: Computational Methods in Chemical Engineering
CH E 132B.prereq_description: Mathematics 4B or 4BI; Mathematics 6A or 6AI; Mathematics 6B and Engineering 3.
CH E 132B.description: Numerical methods for solution of linear and nonlinear algebraic equations, optimization, interpolation, numerical integration and differentiation, initial-value problems in ordinary and partial differential equations, and boundary-value problems.  Emphasis on computational tools for chemical engineering applications.

CH E 132C.title: Statistical Methods in Chemical Engineering
CH E 132C.prereq_description: Mathematics 4B or 4BI; Mathematics 6A or 6AI and Mathematics 6B.
CH E 132C.description: Probability concepts and distributions, random variables, error analysis, point estimation and confidence intervals, hypothesis testing, development of empirical chemical engineering models using regression techniques, design of experiments, process monitoring based on statistical quality control techniques.

CH E 140A.title: Chemical Reaction Engineering
CH E 140A.prereq_description: Chemical Engineering 10 with minimum grade of C-; Chemical Engineering
CH E 140A.description: Fundamentals of chemical reaction engineering with emphasis on kinetics of homogenous and heterogeneous reacting systems. A microkinetic understanding of reaction rates is linked to reactor design, chemical conversion, and selectivity. Batch and continuous reactor designs with and without catalysts are examined.

CH E 140B.title: Chemical Reaction Engineering
CH E 140B.description: Thermodynamics, kinetics, mass and energy transport considerations associated with complex homogeneous and heterogeneous reacting systems. Catalysts and catalytic reaction rates and mechanisms. Adsorption and reaction at solid surfaces, including effects of diffusion in porous materials. Chemical reactors using heterogeneous catalysts.

CH E 141.title: The Science and Engineering of Energy Conversion
CH E 141.prereq_description: Chemical Engineering 110A and 140A or consent of instructor.
CH E 141.comments: Equivalent upper-division coursework in thermodynamics and kinetics from outside of department will be considered.  Same course as CHEM 104.
CH E 141.description: Framework for understanding the energy supply issues facing society with a focus on the science, engineering, and economic principles of the major alternatives.  Emphasis is on the physical and chemical fundamentals of energy conversion technologies.

CH E 146.title: Heterogeneous Catalysis
CH E 146.prereq_description: Chemical Engineering 140A and B or consent of instructor.
CH E 146.description: Concepts and definitions. Applications of heterogeneous catalysis. Performance metrics. Analysis of surface reaction mechanisms and complex reaction networks. Structure-function relationships for supported metal and zeolite catalysts. Synthesis and characterization of heterogeneous catalysts.

CH E 152A.title: Process Dynamics and Control
CH E 152A.description: Development of theoretical and empirical models for chemical and physical processes, dynamic behavior of processes, transfer function and block diagram representation, process instrumentation, control system design and analysis, stability analysis, computer simulation of controlled processes.

CH E 152B.title: Advanced Process Control
CH E 152B.description: The theory, design, and experimental application of advanced process control strategies including feedforward control, cascade control, enhanced single-  loop strategies, and model predictive control. Analysis of multi-loop control systems.  Introduction to on-line optimization.

CH E 154.title: Engineering Approaches to Systems Biology
CH E 154.prereq_description: Chemical Engineering 170 or Chemical Engineering 107; Mathematics 4B or 4BI; Mathematics 6A or 6AI and Mathematics 6B.
CH E 154.description: Applications of engineering tools and methods to solve problems in systems biology. Emphasis is placed on integrative approaches that address multi_scale and multi-rate phenomena in biological regulation. Modeling, optimization, and sensitivity analysis tools are introduced.

CH E 160.title: Introduction to Polymer Science
CH E 160.prereq_description: Chemical Engineering 110A or Chemistry 113A or equivalent.
CH E 160.description: Introductory course covering synthesis, characterization, structure, and mechanical properties of polymers. The course is taught from a materials perspective and includes polymer thermodynamics, chain architecture, measurement and control of molecular weight as well as crystallization and glass transitions.

CH E 166.title: Mechatronics and Instrumentation for Chemical Engineers
CH E 166.prereq_description: Engineering 3 and Chemical Engineering 110A and B, or consent of instructor
CH E 166.description: Introduction to electromechanical systems and instrumentation used in Chemical Engineering. Fundamentals of transducers, sensors and actuators; interfacing and controlling hardware with software (Labview & Matlab programming); analog and digital circuits; hands-on electrical and mechanical design, prototyping, and construction. Students produce a final computer-controlled electromechanical project of their own design, or in conjunction with a ChE-faculty research laboratory.

CH E 170.title: Molecular and Cellular Biology for Engineers
CH E 170.description: Familiarizes engineering students with key concepts from biochemistry, molecular biology, cell biology, and genetics. Students will apply chemical engineering principles to describe different biological systems at multiple scales, including an introduction to bioproduction.

CH E 171.title: Introduction to Biochemical Engineering
CH E 171.description: Introduction to biochemical engineering covering cell growth kinetics, bioreactor design,enzyme processes, biotechnologies for  modification of cellular information, and molecular and cellular engineering.

CH E 173.title: Omics-enabled Biotechnology
CH E 173.prereq_description: Chemical Engineering 170 or Chemical Engineering 107 or MCDB 1A.
CH E 173.description: Integrates genomic, transcriptomic, metabolomic, and proteomic approaches to quantify and understand intricate biological systems. Complementary bioinformatics approaches to curate the large datasets associated with these experiments will also be discussed. Recent examples from the literature will reinforce core concepts, ranging from applications to human health to the environment. By the end of the course, students should be able to design an integrated experiment that capitalizes on these "omics"-based approaches to enhance the scope of their research.

CH E 174.title: Model-Guided Engineering of Biological Systems
CH E 174.prereq_description: Chemical Engineering 10, Chemical Engineering 107 or equivalent or consent of instructor.
CH E 174.description: Introduction to fundamental principles underlying synthetic biology with an emphasis on mathematical modeling of gene regulation using ordinary differential equations and mass action kinetics. Students are introduced to foundational concepts in molecular and cellular engineering, synthetic biology, quantitative modeling of various genetic circuits, as well as cutting edge applications of innovative molecular biotechnologies such as cancer immunotherapy and cell-based diagnostics. Students will also learn to design and predict the functional outcomes of synthetic gene circuits and review primary literature in the field. At the end of this course, students are expected to develop a quantitative understanding of genetic circuit design.

CH E 179.title: Biotechnology Laboratory
CH E 179.prereq_description: Chemical Engineering 170 or MCDB 1A or Chemistry 142A-B or Consent of
CH E 179.comments: Must have an overall grade point average of 3.3 or above.
CH E 179.description: Description:  This course will provide an introduction to theoretical principles and practical methods used in modern biotechnology, genetic engineering, and synthetic biology.  Topics will include protein and cellular engineering using recombinant DNA technologies, mutagenesis, library construction, and biosynthetic display technologies.

CH E 180A.title: Chemical Engineering Laboratory
CH E 180A.description: Experiments in thermodynamics, fluid mechanics, heat transfer, mass transfer, and chemical processing. Analysis of results, and preparation of reports.

CH E 180B.title: Chemical Engineering Laboratory
CH E 180B.description: Experiments in mass transfer, reactor kinetics, process control, and chemical and biochemical processing. Analysis of results, and preparation of reports.

CH E 184A.title: Design of Chemical Processes
CH E 184A.description: Applications of chemical engineering principles to reactor and plant design. Conceptual design of chemical processes. Flowsheeting methods. Engineering cost principles and economic aspects.

CH E 184B.title: Design of Chemical Processes
CH E 184B.description: The solution to comprehensive plant design problems. Use of computer process simulators. Optimization of plant design, investment and operations.

CH E 193.title: Internship in Industry
CH E 193.comments: Student must have a minimum 3.0 GPA. May not be used as departmental elective. May be repeated to a maximum of 12 units.
CH E 193.description: Special projects for selected students. Offered in conjunction with engineering practice in selected industrial and research firms, under direct faculty supervision. A 2-4 page paper and an evaluation from the supervisor will be required for credit.

CH E 196.title: Undergraduate Research
CH E 196.prereq_description: Upper-division standing, completion of 2 upper-division courses in Chemical Engineering; consent of the instructor.
CH E 196.comments: Students must have a minimum 3.0 GPA for the preceding 3 quarters. May be repeated for up to 12 units. Not more than 3 units may be applied to departmental electives.
CH E 196.description: Research opportunities for undergraduate students. Students are expected to give regular oral presentations, actively participate in a weekly seminar, and prepare at least one written report on their research.

CH E 198.title: Independent Studies in Chemical Engineering
CH E 198.prereq_description: Consent of instructor; upper-division standing; completion of 2 upper-division courses in Chemical
CH E 198.comments: Students must have a 3.0 GPA for the preceding 3 quarters. May be repeated up to 12 units. Not more than 3 units may be applied to departmental electives. Students are limited to five units per quarter and 30 units total in all 98/99/198/199/199DC/199RA courses combined.

CH E 202.title: Biomaterials and Biosurfaces
CH E 202.comments: Same course as BMSE 202 and MATRL 270.
CH E 202.description: Fundamentals of natural and artificial biomaterials and biosurfaces with emphasis on molecular level structure and function and their interactions with the body. Design issues of grafts and biopolymers. Basic biological, biophysical and biochemical systems reviewed for nonbiologists.
CH E 202.recommended_prep: Prior biochemistry, physical chemistry, or organic chemistry.

CH E 210A.title: Fundamentals and Applications of Classical Thermodynamics and Statistical Mechanics
CH E 210A.description: Fundamental concepts in classical thermodynamics and statistical mechanics for engineering students. Establishes the framework within which problems can be solved using methodologies that start with molecular level understanding.

CH E 210B.title: Advanced Topics in Equilibrium Statistical Mechanics
CH E 210B.description: Application of the principles of statistical mechanics and thermodynamics to treat classical fluid systems at equilibrium. Topics include liquid state theory, computer simulation methods, critical phenomena and scaling principles, interfacial statistical mechanics, and electrolyte theory.
CH E 210B.recommended_prep: Recommended preparation: a course in physical chemistry.

CH E 210C.title: Statistical Mechanics
CH E 210C.description: Fundamentals of non-equilibrium statistical mechanics, kinetic theory of gases, Boltzmann equation, correlation functions, linear response theory, fluctuation-  dissipation theorem, Langevin and Fokker-Planck equations.

CH E 210D.title: Principles of Modern Molecular Simulation Methods
CH E 210D.description: Provides a broad overview of modern methods for computing the properties of multibody molecular systems. The course will cover: ab initio techniques, classical potential energy functions, Monte Carlo and molecular dynamics methods, free energy calculations, phase equilibria, and self-  assembly/organization.

CH E 211A.title: Matrix Analysis and Computation
CH E 211A.comments: Students should be proficient in basic numerical methods,linear algebra, mathematically rigorous proofs, and some programming language. Same course asComputer Science 211A, ECE 210A, Geology 251A, ME 210A and Mathematics 206A.
CH E 211A.description: Graduate level-matrix theory with introduction to matrix computations. SVD's, pseudoinverses, variational characterization of eigenvalues, perturbation theory, direct and iterative methods for matrix computations.

CH E 211B.title: Numerical Simulation
CH E 211B.comments: Students should be proficient in basic numerical methods, linear algebra, mathematically rigorous proofs, and some programming language. Same course as Computer Science 211B, ECE 210B, Geology 251B, ME 210B and Mathematics 206B.
CH E 211B.description: Linear multistep methods and Runge-Kutta methods for ordinary differential equations: stability, order and convergence. Stiffness. Differential algebraic equations. Numerical solution of boundary value problems.

CH E 211C.title: Numerical Solution of Partial Differential Equations--Finite Difference Methods
CH E 211C.comments: Students should be proficient in basic numerical methods,linear algebra, mathematically rigorous proofs, and some programming language. Same course asComputer Science 211C, ECE 210C, Geology 251C, ME 210C and Mathematics 206C.
CH E 211C.description: Finite difference methods for hyperbolic, parabolic and elliptic PDE's, with application to problems in science and engineering. Convergence, consistency, order and stability of finite difference methods. Dissipation and dispersion. Finite volume methods. Software design and adaptivity.

CH E 211D.title: Numerical Solution of Partial Differential Equations--Finite Element Methods
CH E 211D.comments: Students should be proficient in basic numerical methods, linear algebra, mathematically rigorous proofs, and some programming language. Same course as Computer Science 211D, ECE 210D, Geology 251D, ME 210D, and Mathematics 206D.
CH E 211D.description: Weighted residual and finite element methods for the solution of hyperbolic, parabolic and elliptical partial differential equations, with application to problems in science and engineering. Error estimates. Standard and discontinuous Galerkin methods.

CH E 216A.title: Introduction to Magnetic Resonance Spectroscopy Techniques
CH E 216A.description: An introduction to magnetic resonance theory and experimental techniques, with emphasis on quantum-mechanical descriptions of basic NMR methods for solid-state applications.

CH E 216B.title: Advanced Methods of Magnetic Resonance with Applications to Materials Science
CH E 216B.description: This course is intended to provide an understanding of advanced methods of magnetic resonance spectroscopy and imaging, emphasizing new applications to current issues in materials research.

CH E 220A.title: Advanced Transport Processes-Laminar Flow and Convective Transport Processes
CH E 220A.description: Basic principles of fluid mechanics and convective transport processes. Governing equations and boundary conditions. Non-dimensionalization and scaling. Self-similar solutions and similarity transformations. Unidirectional flows. The thin gap approximation, lubrication theory and thin film dynamics. Low Reynolds number flows.

CH E 220B.title: Advanced Transport Processes-Laminar Flow and Convective Transport Processes
CH E 220B.description: Continuation of ChE 220A. Viscous flows. Application of scaling and asymptotic methods to transport problems and fluid motions; Weak convection effects; Boundary layer theories for fluid mechanics and transport processes. Introduction to Linear stability theory for interfacial and buoyancy-driven flows.

CH E 220C.title: Advanced Transport Processes-Mass Transfer
CH E 220C.description: Basic principles of diffusional processes, multicomponent systems, diffusion with chemical reaction, penetration and surface renewal theories, turbulent transport.

CH E 220D.title: Complex Fluids and Rheology
CH E 220D.description: Microstructural basis of constitutive models for simple "complex fluids" (dilute suspensions of non-spherical Brownian particles). Qualitative physics that leads to viscoelastic behavior in a variety of complex fluids, including polymeric liquids (dilute solutions and melts), wormlike micelle solutions, liquid crystalline fluids, emulsions, gels, and suspensions of vesicles or cells.  Relationship between microscale physics and macroscopic rheology of materials in flow, including spatial non-  uniformities in material properties that arise when flow couples to concentration or molecular weight.

CH E 222.title: Colloids and Biosurfaces
CH E 222.comments: Concurrently offered with Chemical Engineering 121. Not open for credit to students who have completed Chemical Engineering 102.
CH E 222.description: Basic forces and interactions between atoms, molecules, small particles and extended surfaces. Special features and interactions associated with (soft) biological molecules, biomaterials and surfaces: lipids, proteins, fibrous molecules (DNA), biological membranes, hydrophobic and hydrophilic interactions, bio-specific and non-equilibrium interactions. Graduate students do a project on a topic to be proposed by the students, and with a report to be presented to the class at the end of the quarter.
CH E 222.recommended_prep: Basic physical chemistry, chemistry, physics, thermodynamics and biology.

CH E 222A.title: Colloids and Interfaces I
CH E 222A.comments: Same course as Materials 222A and BMSE 222A.
CH E 222A.description: Introduction to the various intermolecular interactions in solutions and in colloidal systems: Van Der Waals, electrostatic, hydrophobic, solvation, H-bonding. Introduction to colloidal systems.

CH E 222B.title: Colloids and Interfaces II
CH E 222B.comments: Materials 222A or Chemical Engineering 222A recommended. Same course as BMSE 222B and Materials 222B.
CH E 222B.description: Continuation of 222A. Interparticle interactions, coagulation, DLVO theory, steric interactions, polymer-coated surfaces, polymers in solution, thin film viscosity. Surfactant and lipid self-assembly: micelles, microemulsions. Surfaces: wetting, contact angles, surface tension. Surfactants on surfaces: langmuir-blodgett films, adsorption, adhesion. Non-equilibrium and dynamic interactions.

CH E 228.title: Non-Newtonian Fluids, Soft Materials and Chemical Products
CH E 228.description: Overview of soft materials (suspensions, gels, polymers, surfactants, emulsions, powders and granules) that arise in diverse industries, including consumer products, foods, advanced materials, biotechnology, and mineral and energy production. Influence of non-Newtonian rheology (shear-thickening and thinning, viscoelasticity, extension-  thickening, yield stresses, normal stress differences, and metastability) upon handling, processing, production, and performance of chemical products. Strategies to design chemical products that meet performance targets, and to scale-up production. Real-world case studies and classroom demonstrations.

CH E 230A.title: Advanced Theoretical Methods in Engineering
CH E 230A.description: Methods of solution of partial differential equations and boundary value problems. Linear vector and function spaces, generalized fourier analysis, Sturm-Liouville theory, calculus of variations, and conformal mapping techniques.

CH E 230B.title: Advanced Theoretical Methods in Engineering
CH E 230B.prereq_description: Chemical Engineering 230A and consent of instructor.
CH E 230B.description: Advanced mathematical methods for engineers and scientists. Complex analysis, integral equations and green's functions. Asymptotic analysis of integrals and sums. Boundary layer methods and WKB theory.

CH E 230D.title: Statistical Methods in Chemical Engineering
CH E 230D.description: An introduction to basic and intermediate statistical, probabilistic, and data analysis methods in engineering: probability functions and their properties, sampling distributions and limits, data collection and statistical inference, hypothesis testing, design of experiments, maximum likelihood and Bayesian methods, linear regression and regularization techniques, nonlinear regression, classification methods, error analysis and model assessment/validation, clustering and data reduction.

CH E 238A.title: Rheology of Complex Fluids
CH E 238A.description: An introduction to molecular and microscale theories for the viscoelastic behavior of complex fluids: suspensions, colloidal dispersions, liquid crystals, dilute polymer solutions.

CH E 240A.title: Advanced Chemical Reaction Engineering
CH E 240A.description: Following review of the theory of reaction kinetics for catalyzed and noncatalyzed systems, detailed consideration is given to design and performance of catalysts and chemical reactors. Mathematical studies of stability and optimization are emphasized in relationship to mass, energy, and momentum transport.

CH E 240B.title: Advanced Chemical Reaction Engineering
CH E 240B.description: Following review of the theory of reaction kinetics for catalyzed and noncatalyzed systems, detailed consideration is given to design and performance of catalysts and chemical reactors. Mathematical studies of stability and optimization are emphasized in relationship to mass, energy, and momentum transport.

CH E 240C.title: Advanced Catalysis
CH E 240C.description: Theories of reaction rates. Heterogeneous and homogenous catalysis, including physical structure and characterization of catalysts. Catalyst poisoning.

CH E 241.title: Advanced Science and Engineering of Energy Conversion
CH E 241.description: The course provides a framework for understanding the energy supply issues facing society with a focus on the science, engineering, and economic principles of the major alternatives.  Emphasis will be on the physical and chemical fundamentals of energy conversion technologies.

CH E 246.title: Advanced Catalysis
CH E 246.description: Theories of reaction rates. Heterogeneous and homogenous catalysis, including physical structure and characterization of catalysts. Catalyst poisoning.

CH E 248.title: Reaction Rate Theory
CH E 248.description: Advanced theoretical and computational methods for the analysis of reaction kinetics and mechanisms. Topics include transition state theory, Kramers' theory, tunneling effects, transition state search algorithms, transition path sampling, kinetic Monte Carlo, reaction coordinate and degree-of-rate-control analyses.

CH E 255.title: Methods in Systems Biology
CH E 255.prereq_description: Prior coursework in cellular biology, mathematics; consent of instuctor.
CH E 255.description: Fundamentals of dynamic network organization in biology (genes, metabolites). Emphasis on mathematical approaches to model and analyze complex biophysical network systems. Detailed case studies demonstrating successes of systems biology. Basic biological systems reviewed for nonbiologists.

CH E 258.title: Protein Design and Engineering
CH E 258.description: Introduction to principles of the development of proteins and peptides for technological applications; including consumer products, materials,  chemicals, biofuels, and medicine. Topics include protein engineering technologies, experimental and computational tools for sequence design, structural and immunogenicity analysis.

CH E 260.title: Introduction to Polymer Science
CH E 260.description: Introductory course covering synthesis, characterization, structure, and mechanical properties of polymers. The course is taught from a materials perspective and includes polymer thermodynamics, chain architecture, measurement and control of molecular weight as well as crystallization and glass transitions.

CH E 266.title: Mechatronics and Instrumentation for Chemical Engineers
CH E 266.description: Introduction to electromechanical systems and instrumentation used in Chemical Engineering. Fundamentals of transducers, sensors and actuators; interfacing and controlling hardware with software (Labview & Matlab programming); analog and digital circuits; hands-on electrical and mechanical design, prototyping, and construction. Students produce a final computer-controlled electromechanical project of their own design, or in conjunction with a ChE-faculty research laboratory. Graduate students taking the course will have an extensive final design project related to some aspect of their thesis research involving automated data acquisition and/or control of instrumentation.

CH E 272.title: Omics-enabled Biotechnology
CH E 272.description: Integrates genomic, transcriptomic, metabolomic, and proteomic approaches to quantify and understand intricate biological systems. Complementary bioinformatics approaches to curate the large datasets associated with these experiments are also discussed. Recent examples from the literature reinforce core concepts, ranging from applications to human health to the environment. By the end of the course, students should be able to design an integrated experiment that capitalizes on these "omics"-  based approaches to enhance the scope of their research.

CH E 274.title: Model-Guided Engineering of Biological Systems
CH E 274.prereq_description: Chemical Engineering 10, Chemical Engineering 107 or equivalent or consent of instructor.
CH E 274.description: Introduction to fundamental principles underlying synthetic biology with an emphasis on mathematical modeling of gene regulation using ordinary differential equations and mass action kinetics. Students are introduced to foundational concepts in molecular and cellular engineering, synthetic biology, quantitative modeling of various genetic circuits, as well as cutting edge applications of innovative molecular biotechnologies such as cancer immunotherapy and cell-based diagnostics. Students will also learn to design and predict the functional outcomes of synthetic gene circuits and review primary literature in the field. Graduate students enrolled will be required to submit an additional project.

CH E 286.title: Model Predictive Control and Moving Horizon Estimation
CH E 286.prereq_description: Linear systems I (ECE 230A or ME 243A) or consent of instructor.
CH E 286.description: Analysis, design and computation of model predictive control applied to  constrained linear, and nonlinear systems. Analysis and design of moving  horizon state estimation of nonlinear systems. As time permits, selected  additional topics include: robust model predictive, stochastic model predictive  control, and identification methods for offset-free model predictive control.

CH E 289A.title: Spectroscopy of Materials
CH E 289A.description: Introduction to continuum and quantum mechanical descriptions of solid materials with emphasis on interactions of light and electrons with matter from an experimental viewpoint. Topics: Maxwell's equations, electron and lattice waves, band theory, photoelectron and various optical spectroscopies.

CH E 290.title: Chemical Engineering Forum
CH E 290.description: Seminars and workshops focusing on current research topics and graduate student education.

CH E 291.title: Research Group Studies
CH E 291.description: Students or instructors present recently published papers and/or results relevant to their own research.

CH E 294B.title: Bioengineering: Career and Development Opportunities at the   Interface between Biotechnology and Engineering
CH E 294B.comments: Quarters usually offered: Spring. Same as BMSE 294B and MCDB 294B.
CH E 294B.description: Based on presentations by experts from the bioengineering industry. Presenters describe their companies' technologies and developments, including biosensors, therapeutics, tissue engineering, quantum dots and advanced instrumentation. Training and educational requirements for different career tracks are discussed.

CH E 493.title: Internship in Industry
CH E 493.description: Special projects for selected students. Students pursue practical engineering experience in selected industrial and research firms, under faculty supervision.

CH E 594.title: Special Topics
CH E 594.description: Special seminar on research subjects of current interest.

CH E 596.title: Directed Reading and Research
CH E 596.description: Experimental or theoretical research undertaken under the direction of a faculty member for graduate students who have not yet advanced to candidacy.

CH E 597.comments: Maximum of 12 units per quarter. S/U grading. Instructor should be the student's major professor or chairman of his doctoral committee. No unit creditallowed toward avanced degree(s). Enrollment limited to 24 units per examination.

CH E 598.title: Master's Thesis Research and Preparation
CH E 598.comments: Not applicable to course requirement for M.S. degree.
CH E 598.description: Only for research underlying the thesis and writing the thesis.

CH E 599.title: Dissertation Research and Preparation
CH E 599.description: Only for research underlying the dissertation and writing the disseration.

CH E W 5.title: Introduction to Chemical Engineering Design
CH E W 5.comments: Cross-listed with ChE 5. Students must be available to meet synchronously once per week via web conference for up to 75 minutes. Synchronous meeting will typically occur on Thursday evenings.
CH E W 5.description: Introduction to the design and analysis of processes involving chemical change in the context of chemical and biomolecular engineering. Students learn mathematical, empirical, and conceptual strategies to analyze chemical processes to assess product quality, economics, safety, and environmental issues. Focus topics include an overview of chemical and biomolecular engineering, evaluating and analyzing data, flowsheets, material and energy balances, economics, and unit operations.
